cyclone.name: ETA
cyclone.current_location: about 140 mi WSW of the Dry Tortugas and 125 mi N of the western tip of Cuba
cyclone.trajectory: Expected to drift southwest this evening, become nearly stationary Tuesday, then turn slowly north and eventually northeast toward the northeastern Gulf of Mexico and the southeastern United States late week.
cyclone.expected_landfall_location: Florida Big Bend / Nature Coast area

weather_observation.watch_coast: None in effect for Georgia; tropical-storm watch only for portions of western Cuba at this time.
weather_observation.impacted_coast: Florida Peninsula, Florida Gulf Coast, Florida Big Bend, southeast Georgia, and portions of South Carolina within the 5-day cone.
weather_observation.rain_fall_above_4_inch: Unlikely (current guidance suggests 1-3 inches for coastal GA)
weather_observation.wind: Low chance (≤11%) of sustained tropical-storm-force winds; occasional gusts 25–35 kt possible late Fri–Sat if center tracks east of forecast.
weather_observation.storm_surge: Minor water-level rises of 1–2 ft above astronomical tides possible on GA barrier islands if onshore flow develops, but major surge not expected.
weather_observation.rainfall: Bands of heavy rain could bring 1–3 in (isolated 4 in) Friday into Saturday, creating localized ponding on port roadways.
weather_observation.other_hazards: Rough seas, higher surf, and dangerous rip currents beginning late week may disrupt pilot transfers and berth operations.
